posts.cooked:
Having communities with sub-groups would make it easier for people to find relevant group chats and keep them organized. It could also increase adoption among those who want to replace something like Slack or Discord, which have servers/communities for different topics with their own sub-groups/channels. In practice this could be implemented like the upcoming ‚ÄúCommunities‚Äù in WhatsApp, but there are probably other ways to do it as well:

TechCrunch ‚Äì 14 Apr 22

WhatsApp to launch structured group chats with admin controls

Meta introduced plans for an update to its WhatsApp messaging app that will allow users to participate in larger discussion groups, called Communities.

Est. reading time: 7 minutes

link_counts.title: WhatsApp to launch ‚ÄòCommunities‚Äô ‚Äî more structured group chats with admin controls ‚Äì TechCrunch

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Facebook is trying to turn WhatsApp into Social Media. Signal shouldn‚Äôt be Social Media.

posts.name: AlertSubject
posts.cooked:
Webex has this feature as well and I wouldn‚Äôt consider it to be social media
Subgroups can useful for teams

I guess Microsoft and slack offer the same feature. But that‚Äôs just a guess

Not sure if signals dev team would focus on such a feature but I wouldn‚Äôt just dismiss it based on ‚Äúit‚Äôs like social media‚Äù
(see stories as an example)

Sorry, but I don‚Äôt see how this would make Signal more like Social Media. I view this more as a quality-of-life feature, akin to having the ability to organize files into folders on a desktop computer. Each ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù would just be a curated collection of group chats. If having group chats makes something Social Media, then Signal is already that but less organized.

What more does this offer compared to having a group which is like an entry point where the group description or members/a bot provides a set of other links for actual content filled groups that people can join?

The UI/UX wouldn‚Äôt be as good. Listing group links in the group description wouldn‚Äôt work well because the description is hidden behind a click/tap and has a maximum character limit. There‚Äôs also no way to send a message to a new member specifically, so older members would see many copies of the same intro message. In both cases, your inbox would contain the sub-groups mixed in with all your other groups. One advantage of having communities with sub-groups is to reduce clutter in the inbox.

posts.name: Ponytail
posts.cooked:
Are communities like ‚ÄòSpaces‚Äô from Element.io?

newuser:

description or members/a bot provides a set of other links

I like the idea, there can be an option to link other groups. It can be displayed below group description, or below the list of members in a group.

Unrelated
Cerberus:

WhatsApp to launch structured group chats with admin controls

The group call UI looks nice.

ponytail:

Are communities like ‚ÄòSpaces‚Äô from Element.io?

I don‚Äôt know how Element.io is, but communities seem similar to servers on Discord where you can have admins and then create multiple chat channels that belong to that server.

If the focus of the feature is on finding and organizing existing group chats, then I think it might be even better if I could categorize or tag chats locally just for myself. That would allow me to categorize chats specifically the way I want to, without requiring a common community.
For example, I might want to tag some chats as ‚Äúchats related to my hobbies / sports‚Äù. The other members of these groups do not share this specific set of hobbies that I have, so in this case there is no common basis to create a shared community.

cascheberg:

I think it might be even better if I could categorize or tag chats locally just for myself.

There‚Äôs a feature request for that.

link_counts.title: Option to *group* chats / create chat folders

posts.cooked:
Given the lack of abuse control currently, in fact, having an entry point group and publishing only that group‚Äôs link with the actual groups not even having a group link seems like a good idea. Mobilecoin is doing something like this.

The entry group needn‚Äôt have anyone who isn‚Äôt interested in vetting the new members.

If there isn‚Äôt going to be any vetting, the group description is probably the best place to advertise the actual groups because it is visible without even joining. The limit on group description is an artificial limit which can be raised (and modified clients can already use the full 8KiB instead of the restricted count on glyphs).

Regarding clutter, I agree with casheberg. Let people organize chats how they want instead of someone else deciding things for them.

ponytail:

Are communities like ‚ÄòSpaces‚Äô from Element.io ?

Seems to be the case from the description in the OP but I have not read the article or know what Whatsapp is doing to say for sure.

1. It‚Äôs way more convenient to join one main group and be automatically in 10 sub-groups rather than having to join 1 groups seperately. Try this with 10 users and you won‚Äôt end up with 10 users in each group‚Ä¶
  2. Users can easily switch their notifications of each sub-group if something changes in their interests over time
  3. Though maybe not being interested in one topic (sub-group) at first users still won‚Äôt miss the contents and can have a look at any time

These are just my first spontaneous thoughts. This is one of my ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your most-missed-feature-ranking?‚Äù features for a long time!

Seven-Sails-Raider:

It‚Äôs way more convenient to join one main group and be automatically in 10 sub-groups rather than having to join 1 groups seperately. Try this with 10 users and you won‚Äôt end up with 10 users in each group‚Ä¶

That doesn‚Äôt appear to be the way that WhatsApp‚Äôs communities work though; it just seems to be a collection of groups that it grants you access to and you still have to choose to join the ones you want to participate in.
Well yeah, I guess you could be right. I don‚Äôt know WhatsApp ('s way of groups).
It is the same with Element‚Äôs Spaces.

Is that important? I won‚Äôt care it it‚Äôs the way or not the way what Discord/WhatsApp/Element/‚Ä¶ do.
It will improve the situation with the same people using different chats to seperate the topics.

posts.name: Quinn Winters
posts.cooked:
WhatsApp allows you to create ‚Äúcommunities‚Äù which are a collection of groups. If you are in one of the groups then you are automatically added to the community. If y ou are in the community then you can see that all the other groups exist, and see the names of the groups, but to join them you still need to be added by an admin for the individual group.

It would be great to see a feature like that enabled in signal with possibly the additional option to allow people to admins to enable anyone in the community to join the group without needing to be manually added

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
I mean, as someone who has several groups which are linked to each other, this would be a nice-to-have, but the way WhatsApp does it is bad. The discord-esque announcement channel especially.
Subgroups is a cool concept, but if you already had a bunch of groups related to each other, it doesn‚Äôt go smoothly. So maybe just an option to link groups to each other would be good, with all of the other management being done manually.

posts.name: AlertSubject
posts.cooked:
I can‚Äôt exactly figure out why but the way whatsapp does it feels very confusing / unintuitive
The linking of subgroups to the primary group feels like a mess. Hard to differentiate

I agree entirely - for large groups its all but unmanageable. I have groups consisting of hundreds of users and the current abilities offered by signal are not indicative of community management ‚Ä¶ they basically are a selling point to use something else.

the only short term solution is to create multiple separate groups - when all thats really needed is the ability to have nested groups and permissions for each.
